content.user_title: Apply Test-Driven Development to Your Code
content.value_statement: AI assistants often skip tests and write code directly. This skill enforces test-first development by requiring failing tests before any implementation. It prevents bugs, documents behavior, and enables safe refactoring for production code.
actual_capabilities: Guides the Red-Green-Refactor TDD cycle step by step
Provides specific code examples for writing failing tests first
Identifies and prevents common testing anti-patterns
Enforces verification of test failures before implementation
Teaches minimal implementation to pass tests only
Explains why test-first catches bugs that tests-after miss
limitations: Does not execute tests or verify code - guides AI behavior only
Does not generate test code automatically - provides patterns for writing tests
Requires human partner approval for exceptions like prototypes
Cannot replace understanding of domain requirements

use_cases.title: Enforce test-first development
use_cases.description: Apply TDD discipline when implementing any feature, ensuring tests exist before production code.

use_cases.title: Verify TDD compliance
use_cases.description: Check that implementation follows Red-Green-Refactor cycle and tests were written first.

use_cases.title: Learn TDD principles
use_cases.description: Understand the Iron Law: no production code without a failing test first.

prompt_templates.title: Start a new feature
prompt_templates.scenario: Begin implementing a feature with TDD
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me implement a new feature using Test-Driven Development. Start by writing a failing test that describes the desired behavior. Wait for my approval of the test before writing any implementation code.

prompt_templates.title: Fix a bug with TDD
prompt_templates.prompt: We have a bug where empty email is accepted. Apply TDD to fix it: first write a test that reproduces the bug by expecting validation to fail for empty email, then implement the fix.

prompt_templates.title: Refactor safely
prompt_templates.scenario: Clean up code while keeping tests green
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me refactor this code using TDD principles. First verify the current tests pass, then identify what to improve, write tests for any new behavior, and refactor while keeping all tests green.

prompt_templates.title: Review TDD process
prompt_templates.prompt: Review the current code and tests. Check if tests were written first by verifying each test fails meaningfully before implementation. Identify any violations of TDD principles and suggest corrections.

output_examples.input: Help me add a function that validates passwords must be at least 8 characters
output: I will apply TDD. First, let me write a failing test:
expect(result.error).toBe('Password must be at least 8 characters');
Please review this test. Once you approve, I will run it to verify it fails, then implement the minimal code to pass it.

output_examples.input: I need to add user authentication
output: I will apply TDD to authentication. Let me start with one minimal failing test for the login functionality:
Please review this test. Once you approve, I will run it to verify it fails, then implement the minimal authentication code to pass it.

best_practices: Always verify tests fail for the right reason before implementing - this proves the test catches the actual issue
Write minimal code to pass the test only - resist adding features or refactoring during the Green phase
Delete implementation code written before tests - start fresh from tests only to maintain TDD discipline
anti_patterns: Writing code before tests - even reference code must be deleted and rewritten from tests
Testing mock behavior instead of real behavior - mocks isolate, they are not the thing being tested
Adding test-only methods to production code - move test utilities to separate files instead

faq.question: What if the feature is too simple to test?
faq.answer: Simple code still breaks. Tests take 30 seconds and prove the behavior works. Simple features benefit most from tests.

faq.question: Can I write tests after implementing to save time?
faq.answer: Tests-after prove nothing. They pass immediately because you tested what you built, not what was required. Test-first proves the test catches bugs.

faq.question: What about prototypes and exploration?
faq.answer: Exploration is fine, but throw it away. Start fresh with TDD. Exploration helps you understand, but it is not production code.

faq.question: How do I handle external APIs in tests?
faq.answer: Mock at the right level. Understand what side effects the real method has before mocking. Mock too high and you break test logic.

faq.question: When should I add more tests?
faq.answer: After Refactor phase, add the next failing test for the next behavior. One behavior per test keeps tests focused and maintainable.

faq.question: What if I cannot figure out how to test something?
faq.answer: Write the assertion first. Describe what you wish the API looked like. Ask your human partner for clarification on requirements.
